original_data.question: A 25-year-old, G2P2L2 woman presents with a complaint of missed menstrual cycle for 4 weeks. Her previous menstrual cycles were regular, occurring every 28â€“35 days consistently. The patient does not have any other complaints currently. Her past medical history reveals two uncomplicated and normal vaginal deliveries at term. She has a 2-year-old boy and a 6-month-old girl. The patient and her partner use the withdrawal method for contraception. The urine pregnancy test result is positive. The patient returns to the clinic after 1 week expressing her desire to discontinue with the pregnancy and inquires about the possibility of an elective abortion. Which of the following procedures is the most appropriate for elective termination of pregnancy in this patient?

model_response:
The most appropriate procedure for elective termination of pregnancy in this patient is manual uterine aspiration. Manual uterine aspiration, also known as "menstrual regulation," is the most commonly used method for first-trimester abortion in India and China. This method is used for pregnancies of less than 12 weeks' gestation. A sterile speculum is used to expose the cervix, and a plastic cannula is inserted into the uterine cavity. The suction is turned on, and the cavity is emptied by gentle but thorough aspiration. Dilatation and evacuation (D&E) is the most common second-trimester abortion procedure. In this procedure, the cervix is dilated, and the fetal parts are removed using a combination of suction and forceps. Oxytocin-induced labor is the most common method for second-trimester abortion in the United States. In this procedure, high doses of oxytocin are used to induce labor and deliver the fetus. Oral mifepristone plus misoprostol is a medical method for first-trimester abortion. Mifepristone is a progesterone antagonist that causes decidual breakdown. It is followed in 24-48 hours by misoprostol, which is a prostaglandin analogue.

###Answer: OPTION C IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human females as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
Not existing; not able to be found.

The period from onset of one menstrual bleeding (MENSTRUATION) to the next in an ovulating woman or female primate. The menstrual cycle is regulated by endocrine interactions of the HYPOTHALAMUS; the PITUITARY GLAND; the ovaries; and the genital tract. The menstrual cycle is divided by OVULATION into two phases. Based on the endocrine status of the OVARY, there is a FOLLICULAR PHASE and a LUTEAL PHASE. Based on the response in the ENDOMETRIUM, the menstrual cycle is divided into a proliferative and a secretory phase.
Any period of seven consecutive days.

The periodic shedding of the ENDOMETRIUM and associated menstrual bleeding in the MENSTRUAL CYCLE of humans and primates. Menstruation is due to the decline in circulating PROGESTERONE, and occurs at the late LUTEAL PHASE when LUTEOLYSIS of the CORPUS LUTEUM takes place.
An event or sequence of events that constitute a round or succession of observable phenomena, recurring usually at regular or approximately regular time intervals and in the same sequence.
The time for Earth to make a complete rotation on its axis; ordinarily divided into twenty-four hours, equal to 86 400 seconds. This also refers to a specific day.
Marked by a reasonable or logical relation of parts and holding together as a harmonious or credible whole.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
A symptom or problem for which a patient seeks medical attention.
A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies.
The genital canal in the female, extending from the UTERUS to the VULVA. (Stedman, 25th ed)
Birth at greater than or equal to 37 weeks using best estimated due date.
Human females as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
To cease active participation in; remove from active use.

Prevention of CONCEPTION by blocking fertility temporarily, or permanently (STERILIZATION, REPRODUCTIVE). Common means of reversible contraception include NATURAL FAMILY PLANNING METHODS; CONTRACEPTIVE AGENTS; or CONTRACEPTIVE DEVICES.
Involving advantage or good.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
To give something back, or the getting back thereof.
Those facilities which administer health services to individuals who do not require hospitalization or institutionalization.
Any period of seven consecutive days.
The phenotypic manifestation of a gene or genes by the processes of GENETIC TRANSCRIPTION and GENETIC TRANSLATION.
Definition:A desire to have an act occur.
To stop or end, permanently or temporarily.
The status during which female mammals carry their developing young (EMBRYOS or FETUSES) in utero before birth, beginning from FERTILIZATION to BIRTH.
A surgical or medical procedure that terminates a pregnancy by removing the products of conception.
Used with techniques, procedures, and programs for methods.
**Definition:**The event occurred in order to terminate the subject's participation in the study.
The status during which female mammals carry their developing young (EMBRYOS or FETUSES) in utero before birth, beginning from FERTILIZATION to BIRTH.
